awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the controls on spatial and temporal variability in ice discharge using a Greenland-wide ice sheet model

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Greenland Ice Sheet is the second largest ice sheet in the world. If all the ice in Greenland melted, global sea-level would rise by over 7m (23ft). Greenland loses ice by melting at the surface and by flowing into the ocean through outlet glaciers, large rivers of ice ending in narrow fjords that drain the interior of the ice sheet.

 

The overall goal of this project was to better understand what happens when the ice comes in contact with the ocean waters and to make a computer model that can simulate these processes. When the ice meets the ocean it can either break off (known as ?calving?) or it melts. Which of the two processes dominates depends on several factors, including the temperature and the salinity of the ocean water and the stresses that occur in the ice when it flows. Using satellite observations of how fast the ice flows we calculated the stresses in the ice and then estimated the amount of ice that calves into the ocean. Next, we compared our calving estimates to other studies that calculated the amount of ice that melts when it comes in contact with the ocean. Then we used this information to calibrate our computer model.

 

In a second step we calibrated the model such that it does a good job reproducing present day mass loss. We then used the calibrated model to find look into the future of the Greenland Ice Sheet. However, no computer model is perfect and there are many processes that we still do not yet full understand. We ran the model hundreds times with slightly varying assumptions to account for these uncertainties as well as we could. The results are thus not a single number but ranges: we find that Greenland could contribute 5 to 28 cm to sea level by 2100, with discharge from outlet glaciers contributing 8 to 45% of total mass loss. Looking even further into the future, we find that there is a possibility that all ice could disappear with about a thousand years. Whether this will really happen depends on the amount of greenhouse gas emission in the near future.
